body: Your stack traces for the allocations would be appreciated. One thing to avoid fragmentation is not to allocate in a loop Ort objects such Ort::Session and alike. Those objects are extremely small, and their purpose to act as smart pointers to prevent leaks. So wrapping them again into smart pointers does not make sense. It is not Java.

Only run is called in the loop. Session is created during initialization, of course. Why does calling the run fuction allocate heap memory? Btw. I am a C++ and C# guy :)
________________________________
From: Dmitri Smirnov ***@***.***>
Sent: Tuesday, April 20, 2021 9:47:44 PM
To: microsoft/onnxruntime ***@***.***>
Cc: PhilippPaetzold ***@***.***>; Author ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [microsoft/onnxruntime] Avoid allocations and memory leak in performance critical loop (#7381)


You stack traces for the allocations would be appreciated. One thing to avoid fragmentation is not to allocate in a loop Ort objects such Ort::Session and alike. Those objects are extremely small, and their purpose to act as smart pointers to prevent leaks. So wrapping them again into smart pointers does not make sense. It is not Java.

â€”
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/7381#issuecomment-823554987>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AFTQECH7LLG3D2I3MNVWC5LTJXK6BANCNFSM43IPGGHQ>.

How many allocations do you see if you use the CPU execution provided (EP)  instead of the OpenVINO EP? The ORT EPs generally use arenas to minimize system calls. Not sure what OpenVINO does internally though. 

Looking at a sample of the stack traces for some of the new/delete allocations you're intercepting would also be helpful to see which library they're coming from.
@skottmckay Thanks for your reply. I will switch to CPU execution and get you the numbers and also provide some stack traces.

`std::allocator` is not special, it is a standard default allocator.
`inputLayer` and `outputLayer` names and output names are supposed to be freed by the caller using the same allocator provided.. Example code has a bug. [doc](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/09313d9e1f2cb526330369eee88b489b23dd2c4f/include/onnxruntime/core/session/onnxruntime_c_api.h#L494)

However, that it is just a part of the picture.
Ok, we will switch to a different framework then. Thank you for your support.

We use memory pool for all the data allocations (i.e. all the tensors and weights used during model execution), but don't override the std::allocator for things like std::string and std::vector. 

Originally you mentioned way over a million allocations when using the OpenVINO EP though, so given with the CPU EP the number of allocations seems to be much smaller there's a good chance OpenVINO is not using a memory pool (so a different framework that uses OpenVINO may have the same issue).

The 'leaking' allocator could be the allocation of a buffer for the memory pool. It will be freed when the session is freed.
